newsitem.title: USA: N.J. colleges say need more state aid -- paper.
newsitem.headline: N.J. colleges say need more state aid -- paper.

text.p: Tuition at New Jersey's colleges and universities will increase this fall unless the Whitman Administration adds more state aid to the budget, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported Tuesday.
In testimony before the Senate budget committee, which is considering Gov. Christine Whitman's fiscal 1998 spending plan, college presidents outlined plans to raise prices next year.
Whitman's state aid plan envisions $732 million of aid next year, unchanged from 1997 levels despite salary increases required by new contracts.
College and university officials said they wanted a hike of $40 million in state aid.

The state Treasurer's office has argued that colleges and universities have been sitting on surpluses that could be used to pay higher costs. But college presidents argued that the use of that money is restricted.
